channel.title: Byte operators? @#&*!
channel.description:
Ok, I know much of java (not all of it), and the only thing I need to know about is bytes! I have no clue how >> and << or &= or |= work, and the creation of my program requires operations on bytes. I've been on Google, and it always gives me links to sites where they assume you already know these operators.
Help would be appreciated.

item.title: Byte operators? @#&*!
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

Yes, you can’t assign a value to another value. You need to invoke PrintStream.println(int) with 0 iand 1

Read full topic

item.title: Byte operators? @#&*!
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

yakman:

I wrote a tutorial about these once, it was meant for SCAR, but the same applies for other languages, and I included the symbols for C-based languages (of which java is included)

I’d like to check it out.

Moparisthebest:

You can leave out the extra +"", since println takes an argument of byte as well.

System.out.println(0 |= 1); =

Main.java:18: unexpected type required: variable found : value System.out.println(0 &= 1); 1 error

but System.out.println(0 | 1); works… Does the = sign matter?

Read full topic

item.title: Byte operators? @#&*!
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

you need to learn base 2 first

Read full topic

item.title: Byte operators? @#&*!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Rajae, post:5, topic:158319”]Alright, I could do that, but how would I print it into the command-line?

System.out.println(byte+"");

?[/quote]

You can leave out the extra +"", since println takes an argument of byte as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Byte operators? @#&*!
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“Rajae, post:5, topic:158319”]Alright, I could do that, but how would I print it into the command-line?

System.out.println(byte+"");

?[/quote]

you start of by :

System.out.println( 0 &= 1);

and see what happens
and do that same thing for ^, and |, and <<, >>

and you keep switching 0 and 1 with other numbers till u get the rhythm

Read full topic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

A great way to learn what they do is just do perform them and print them out, when you get where you can guess(know) what will happen then you have it down.
